page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY - 1
page.content: The name Charlton Kings is derived from "Ceorlton" meaning 'a peasant's farmstead belonging to the Crown (as opposed to a monastery)". Old industries can be seen in local names: Ryeworth was an enclosure for growing rye; Sappercombe was the soap-makers valley and Crab End was where the crab apples were grown. Battledown was a farmstead or tun belonging to Badella. The oldest surviving building is the parish church, St Mary's, which was started in 1190. In 1290 a chantry chapel was added with a priest's room above, of which the fireplace and half-timbering are still visible. A piscina in the chapel has an ogee arch which allows accurate dating. The tower was built in 1390. As the congregation grew, the church was extended and galleries added until a major rebuilding in Victorian times.
